awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Grounding Institutional Partnerships in Structures for Broader Impacts Design
awd_abstract_narration:
As higher education institutions (HEIs) work to enhance Broader Impacts (BI) efforts, collaborations with informal science education institutions (ISEs) (e.g. science centers, aquaria, zoos) can help them strengthen their impact and reach broader audiences.  This project builds on the successful Portal to the Public (PoP) framework, bringing together the expertise and resources of HEIs and ISEs around the shared mission of engaging public audiences in current STEM research. The project is designed to address several critical needs: (1) Public outreach BI activities are relatively uncommon compared to BI that is focused within the infrastructure of academia; (2) Because collaborations with ISEs are frequently tied to individual Principal Investigators (PIs), there is limited opportunity to build a body of knowledge around the practice of partnering for BI work; and (3) Collaborations are often transient, making it more difficult for universities to view BI on an institutional level in ways that leverage particular institutional assets or strategies and even link investigators from multiple projects.

The specific areas of study are: 
a.  Develop and test a structure for education/outreach BI experience design that addresses a public audience need and meets NSF's BI criterion: The project will create disseminatable tools around the activity design process (including evaluation of learning impacts). By convening cross-disciplinary teams, the project will ensure that experiences will reflect a wide range of expertise and will help meet the needs of multiple stakeholders. These established structures will lower the barrier to entry for PIs who want to do public outreach BI.

b.  Design, test, and study structures for long-term, mutually beneficial HEI-ISE partnerships: The project will build on the proven PoP model to create flexible, disseminatable tools around the development of institutional partnerships at three collaborating HEI-ISE site pairings that consider each institution's resources, constraints and strategic goals, including a cross-institutional and cross-disciplinary Broader Impacts Design (BID) Team structure. Sustained partnerships will support ongoing public engagement with current STEM research.

c.  Anchor the partnership at the HEI with a representative from an office of research support: Research support professionals will be a core part of the BID Team and will help support institutional strategies for aligning BI activities with broader goals around community engagement.

d.  Study the culture of HEI-ISE partnerships, building knowledge about how these institutions can form effective, sustained and mutually beneficial collaborations.

Project partners include Pacific Science Center with the University of Washington, Bothell, WA; University of Wisconsin-Madison with the Wisconsin Institute for Discovery; and the Sciencenter with Cornell University, Ithaca, NY.  In addition, the Center for Research in Lifelong Learning, Oregon State University will oversee the research aspects of the project. The project's primary benefit is the development of more effective mechanisms for HEIs and ISEs to collaborate, that will better enable them to engage their communities in experiences and conversations about current STEM research and innovation.

This project is being funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program, which seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments.

Summary

The Oregon State University STEM Research Center served as the research and evaluation partners on the Collaborative Partnerships for Broader Impacts Design project. The project aimed at supporting informal science education organizations (such as museums, zoos, and science-technology centers) and higher education institutions (such as universities) develop and sustain robust and mutually beneficial partnerships around fulfilling broader impacts of university-based R&D. The research team studied and evaluated the practices of nine such teams, each working to connect scientists with public audiences and public audiences with scientists to determine whether, how and under what circumstances such partnerships can succeed.

 

Intellectual Merit

Three key recommendations emerge from this work:

1. Participants in partnerships which focused on day-to-day practices and the way they responded to common challenges around current needs were more satisfied with their progress and expressed a stronger understanding of mutual goals than those which focused mostly on institutionalization of their museum-university partnership.

2. Embracing and thoughtfully attending to the dynamic nature of interorganizational partnerships between informal science education providers and universities can enable or support the development of a collaborative regional network of broader impacts partners.

3. Strong interpersonal relationships and trust between participants in the collaboration, along with continued efforts to maintain organizational buy-in in each setting, may be prerequisites for transitioning a two-organization partnership into a regional network.

 

Five publications provide extensive details on the research and evaluation findings:

Risien, J., Hoke, K. and Fleming, T. (in press). Institutional Infrastructures to Enhance Broader Impacts. In (Eds.) VanEgeren, L. and Renoe, S. The Scholarship of Engagement Book Series: Handbook for Broader Impacts (in press). East Lansing, MI: Michigan State University Press. 

Risien, J., Hoke, K., Storksdieck, M., Davis, C. and Klein, E. (in review. A dynamic framework for making sense of partnerships between universities and informal education providers. 

Risien, J., Nilson, R., Storksdieck, M., & Hoke, K. (2022). BID partnership pulse check: Survey tool for monitoring partnership health Corvallis, OR: STEM Research Center. DOI: https://doi.org/10.5399/osu/1155

Hoke, K., & Risien, J. (2021). Grounding Institutional Partnerships in Structures for Broader Impact Design: Summative Evaluation Report. STEM Research Center: Oregon State University. https://doi.org/10.5399/osu/1151

Hoke, K. & Risien, J. (2019). Collaborative Research: Grounding Institutional Partnerships in Structures for Broader Impact Design Mid-Way Evaluation Report. Corvallis, OR: Center for Research on Lifelong STEM Learning. https://doi.org/10.5399/osu/1136

 

Broader impacts

The project offers a conceptual framework to help partners, scientist and organizational leaders make sense of complex interorganizational partnerships that support public engagement with science. This framework can guide design, practices, and evaluation of interorganizational partnerships seeking to improve and expand broader impacts through public engagement with science. The framework provides partners with evidence-based advice on how to recognize and address changing organizational and societal conditions through reflective conversations that improve mutual understanding of the people, organizations, and communities relevant to the partnership. Those who design, facilitate, evaluate or lead interorganizational collaborations can use the framework to better understand and continuously improve the health of their partnerships. This framework will also support partners who wish to grow the reach and value of their work by serving as a catalyst for the development and nurturing of a network of regional organizations committed to advancing the societal impacts of research investments.

The research results and emerging framework was shared with practitioners and scholars via a chapter in the Handbook on Broader Impacts, a widely anticipated anthology associated with the NSF-funded Broader Impacts support Center Advancing Research in Society. The chapter describes how universities can work to develop the organizational capacity to better support public engagement with science via partnering with informal science education organizations.  

To reach a broader audience of practitioners, the STEM Research Center produced a podcast, Stop, Collaborate and Listen! This podcast shares key insights and lessons learned in support of university and science center colleagues in their endeavors to advance societal impacts of research investment through public engagement with science. The podcast includes six episodes, each with expert guests. It is available on many platforms including Spotify https://open.spotify.com/show/0MhKudMt9zRS5gvpodlq3w?si=e8ad87a9cd33481b. All resources mentioned in the episodes which were created in collaboration with the Institute for Learning Innovation, as well as transcripts, can be found here: https://linktr.ee/sclpodcast.
